1.text: Dead flies cause the ointment of the apothecary to send forth an offensive odor: so doth a little folly him that is in reputation for wisdom and honor.

2.text: A wise man’s heart is at his right hand; but a fool’s heart is at his left.

3.text: Also, when he that is a fool walketh by the way, his wisdom faileth him, and he saith to every one that he is a fool.

4.text: If the spirit of the ruler riseth against thee, leave not thy place; for yielding pacifieth great offenses.

5.text: There is an evil which I have seen under the sun, as an error which proceedeth from the ruler:

6.text: Folly is set in great dignity, and the rich sit in low place.

7.text: I have seen servants upon horses, and princes walking as servants upon the earth.

8.text: He that diggeth a pit shall fall into it; and whoever breaketh a hedge, a serpent shall bite him.

9.text: Whoever removeth stones shall be hurt by them; and he that cleaveth wood shall be endangered by it.

10.text: If the iron is blunt, and he doth not whet the edge, then must he use more strength: but wisdom is profitable to direct.

11.text: Surely the serpent will bite without enchantment; and a babbler is no better.

12.text: The words of a wise man’s mouth are gracious; but the lips of a fool will swallow up himself.

13.text: The beginning of the words of his mouth is foolishness: and the end of his talk is mischievous madness.

14.text: A fool also is full of words: a man cannot tell what shall be; and what shall be after him, who can tell him?

15.text: The labor of the foolish wearieth every one of them, because he knoweth not how to go to the city.

16.text: Woe to thee, O land, when thy king is a child, and thy princes eat in the morning!

17.text: Blessed art thou, O land, when thy king is the son of nobles, and thy princes eat in due season, for strength, and not for drunkenness!

18.text: By much slothfulness the building decayeth; and through idleness of the hands the house droppeth through.

19.text: A feast is made for laughter, and wine maketh merry: but money answereth all things.

20.text: Curse not the king, no not in thy thought; and curse not the rich in thy bed-chamber: for a bird of the air will carry the voice, and that which hath wings will tell the matter.
